title: 115_s850
content: The "Foreign Medical School Accountability Fairness Act of 2017" aims to establish consistent eligibility requirements for graduate medical schools outside the US and Canada to increase accountability and protect American students and taxpayer dollars. Congress finds that three for-profit schools in the Caribbean receive the majority of Federal funding under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 for students enrolled at foreign graduate medical schools, despite being exempt from meeting the same eligibility requirements as other schools. The National Committee on Foreign Medical Education and Accreditation recommend that all foreign graduate medical schools should meet consistent requirements. The National Committee on Foreign Medical Education and Accreditation recommends that all foreign graduate medical schools should meet the same eligibility requirements to participate in Federal funding under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The attrition rate at United States medical schools is 3.4 percent, while for-profit Caribbean medical schools have rates reaching 30 percent. In 2016, residency match rates for foreign trained graduates averaged 54 percent compared to 94 percent for graduates of medical schools in the United States. Students at for-profit medical schools outside of the United States and Canada accumulate more debt on average. In 2016, foreign trained graduates had a residency match rate of 54%, while US medical school graduates had a rate of 94%. Students at for-profit medical schools outside the US and Canada accumulate more debt on average. SEC. 4. REPEAL GRANDFATHER PROVISIONS. Section 102(a)(2) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require that at least 60 percent of enrolled and graduating students in a foreign medical school are not individuals described in a specific section. The Higher Education Act of 1965 amendment mandates that 60 percent of students in foreign medical schools are not individuals described in a specific section. The Higher Education Act of 1965 amendment requires that at least 75 percent of students or graduates from foreign medical schools taking certain exams are not individuals from the United States or Canada. The Higher Education Act of 1965 amendment mandates that a majority of students or graduates from foreign medical schools taking specific exams are not from the United States or Canada. Additionally, students seeking loans under part D of title IV must have received a passing score on exams administered by the Educational Commission for Foreign Medical Graduates in the previous year. Medical graduates must have received a passing score on exams from the previous year to qualify for loans under part D of title IV. The authority of a graduate medical school to participate in loan programs under title IV expires after a certain period. The authority of a graduate medical school to qualify for loan programs under title IV expires after a certain period following the enactment of the Foreign Medical School Accountability Fairness Act of 2017. The eligibility for loan programs under title IV for graduate medical schools expires after a certain period following the enactment of the Foreign Medical School Accountability Fairness Act of 2017. If a graduate medical school loses eligibility for loan programs under title IV due to certain amendments, enrolled students can still receive loans while meeting academic progress requirements. Students enrolled in a graduate medical school that loses eligibility for loan programs can still receive loans if they meet academic progress requirements until they withdraw, complete their program, or reach the fourth June 30 after the loss of eligibility.
